job_title: Marketing And Communications Manager in Birmingham, England
pros: I have been with Housing 21 for 8 months now and have been made to feel incredibly welcome and supported here. My line-manager gave me a fantastic onboarding experience, my team have been super-friendly and helpful, and the benefits and flexible-working arrangements all cement my decision as the right one to join Housing 21!
cons: Be prepared to roll your sleeves up and get stuck in. The work can be hard at times, but you'll get out of it what you put in, so don't shy away from the tougher times, as there's a lot of fun and job satisfaction to be had here.

job_title: Court Manager in Sunderland, North East England, England

job_title: Home Health Care Administrator in Hemel Hempstead, England
pros: The residents and carers where all lovely people who put up with a lot of neglect and disrespect from the manager.
cons: The manager publicly reminded me how useless I was on a daily basis because of my disability. She even verbally insulted me in front of witnesses on one occasion. I left, I complained to HR, they refused to tell me the outcome, GDPR apparently. No faith in a company who employs someone like that and leaves them unchecked and unsupervised. There's lots more that happened that will stay with me as I've never met a manager so nasty for years. Didn't help my self esteem as I was trying to come to terms with my disability at the time, still am.

pros: Only pro is working onsite
cons: Too many managers in one place with too many different expectations. Work load is dangerous, not enough carers on rotas

pros: Always looking to change things

job_title: National Compliance Manager in Birmingham, England
pros:
I have been employed at Housing 21 for 7 years and have therefore experienced the difference that Bruce’s leadership has made. Where things were previously chaotic, we now have a clear sense of direction and a genuine care for the services that we deliver.

From a personal perspective, I have been provided with development opportunities both during my tenure within the Procurement Team and now Asset Management and have commenced a degree via the apprenticeship levy which has been a lifelong goal. You are very much in control of your personal development and are encouraged to seek training externally although there are a raft of training courses and knowledge bites available internally via the e-learning platform. 

Communication during the pandemic has been fantastic, with regular updates from Bruce and via the intranet. 

All-in-all, a great company to work for an plenty of opportunity if you are seeking longevity and career development.
cons: None. Keep up the great work!

pros: 2 weekly pay supportive colleagues
cons: Rubbish management. Don’t listen to staff only look out for themselves

job_title: Human Resources Assistant in Birmingham, England
pros: Development opportunities to develop, great leadership and values. Great team however 1 or 2 negative team mates who spoil things for others but that happens in all organisations. I learnt lots and was able to use my experience with the company to progress my career.
cons: Operational staff have no regard for the pressure on corporate staff. There is often lots of blame put on the HR department. Senior management is often detached from junior level employees which can be frustrating.

pros: Flexible working, hands on executive team.

pros:
paid weekly 
meeting some lovely people
cons:
gaps in calls so you are at work for a hour or two and then you go home 
don't get paid travel time so you can start work at 7am and finish at 10pm and only get paid at least 5-7 hours of that time 

not very good customer service on the phone they expect you to cover your own calls aswell as someone elses if they have gone off sick which makes you late for everything. 

doesn't know there own geographical location I got rang up to cover someones morning calls aswell as my own and this place was over 40miles away?

training is basic 

aren't concerned with any problems that has happened with a client or a team worker 


decide not to tell you that the office has closed down after they have lost the care contract in the county

pros: Such a positive atmosphere, everyone is helpful and regularly trained in all aspects to ensure their knowledge is up to date. Good perks at head office such as a new gym in the basement, free parking. Staff are friendly, there's no blame culture thankfully. Management are flexible, friendly and approachable. I really enjoy my role and often there are chances to be seconded to other roles or be promoted if you are qualified enough. Very charity-minded, inclusive and forward thinking company.
cons: It would be hard to criticise anything at Housing21 but I guess when people leave it would be preferable if their replacements were recruited quicker to ensure work doesn't build up. Otherwise I really cannot think of a negative, after working at a few quite poorly run companies in the past, this feels like heaven!

pros: Job satisfaction, support and guidance when needed, intranet provides communication from all different departments ensuring all are aware of what is going on within the company as a whole as well as a communications weekly newsletter.
cons: Because of working with elderly people there are lots of emotions to deal with as ultimately people pass away and as you deal with them on a daily basis you get to know them better than their own families at these late stages in life.

review_title: Good people, good company, lots of change
